sen.j: 藪内流（やぶのうちりゅう）は茶道流派の一つ。
sen.e: The Yabunouchi school is one of the schools of tea ceremony.
The Yabunouchi-ryu is a school of the tea ceremony.
The Yabunouchi-ryu is a school of the tea ceremony.

sen.j: 古儀茶道藪内流とも。
sen.e: It is also called the Yabunouchi school, tea ceremony of ancient rites.
It is also known as the Yabunouchi Old Tea Ceremony School.
It is also known as the Yabunouchi Old Tea Ceremony School.

sen.j: 浮薄を戒め千利休時代の茶風を留めているとされるが、これは武野紹鴎・利休の侘び茶に古田重然の武家茶の影響をいれたものである。
sen.e: It keeps the style of tea ceremony in the period of SEN no Rikyu, emphasizing avoidance of frivolousness; it is the mix of wabicha (literally, "poverty tea style"; known as the tea ceremony) led by Jo TAKENO/Rikyu with an influence of tea manners of samurai family led by Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA.

It keeps the style of tea ceremony in the period of SEN no Rikyu, emphasizing avoidance of frivolousness; it is the mix of wabicha (literally, "poverty tea style"; known as the tea ceremony) led by Jo TAKENO/Rikyu with an influence of tea manners of samurai family led by Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA.

It keeps the style of tea ceremony in the period of SEN no Rikyu, emphasizing avoidance of frivolousness; it is the mix of wabicha (literally, "poverty tea style"; known as the tea ceremony) led by Jouou TAKENO/Rikyu with an influence of tea manners of samurai family led by Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA.
sen.cmt: 紹鴎→「じょうおう」ですが、「Jouou」としました。

sen.j: 庵号は燕庵（えんなん）といい、織部の考案による相伴席付三畳台目の茶室を指す。
sen.e: The name of hermitage is Ennan, meaning a tea room of 6.19 square meters (3 tatami mats and one daimedatami mat) with seats for participating, which was invented by Oribe.
The tea house, based on a design by Oribe, is called Ennan and is 6.19 square meters (3 tatami mats and one daimedatami mat) with seats for participants.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity- Although not in the original, I don't know if it's worth mentioning that Oribe and Shigenari Furuta were the same person
sen.e: The tea house, based on a design by Oribe, is called Ennan and is 6.19 square meters (3 tatami mats and one daimedatami mat) with seats for participants.

sen.j: 家元藪内家は京都市下京区西洞院通正面下にあり、このため上京区にある上流（三千家）に対して下流と呼び習わされてきた。
sen.e: The Yabunouchi family, the head of the school, is located on the lower front of Nishi-no-Toin-dori Street, Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City so that it has been called the Shimo (the lower) school compared to the Kami (the upper) schools (Sansenke, three schools of tea ceremony (Omotesenke, Urasenke, and Mushakojisenke)), which are located in Kamigyo Ward.

Since the school's head family, the Yabunouchi family, is based at Nishinotoin-dori Street, Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, it is commonly called the Lower (shimo) School, as opposed to the Sansenke schools (Omotesenke, Urasenke, and Mushakojisenke) located in Kamigyo Ward and known as the Upper (kami) Schools.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - the "正面下" of the address indicates that it is south of the junction of "西洞院通" and "正面通". I feel it doesn't add much information for English speakers so I left it out.
sen.e: Since the school's head family, the Yabunouchi family, is based at Nishinotoin-dori Street, Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, it is commonly called the Lower (shimo) School, as opposed to the Sansenke schools (Omotesenke, Urasenke, and Mushakojisenke) located in Kamigyo Ward and known as the Upper (kami) Schools.

sen.j: 財団法人として薮内燕庵、同門組織としては竹風会がある。
sen.e: Ennan YABUNOUCHI is its foundation, and the Chikufukai group is an organization of the school.
The school also runs the Ennan Yabunouchi Foundation and the Chikufukai students' organization.
The school also runs the Ennan Yabunouchi Foundation and the Chikufukai students' organization.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 藪内家の遠祖は藪宗把といい、足利義政の同胞衆であり、茶道の奥義にも通じていたという。
sen.e: The forefather of the Yabunouchi family was Soha YABU, who was a Doboshu (attendant) of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA with much knowledge of secrets of tea ceremony.
A forefather of the Yabunouchi family was Soha YABU, Shogun Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA's doboshu (adviser specializing in the arts), who was well-versed in the secrets of the tea ceremony.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - changed explanation of "同胞衆"Articles
sen.e: A forefather of the Yabunouchi family was Soha YABU, Shogun Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA's doboshu (adviser specializing in the arts), who was well-versed in the secrets of the tea ceremony.

sen.j: 初代藪内剣仲は武野紹鴎の門下で、兄弟子の千利休とは親交が深く、利休より相伝を受け、また利休の媒酌によって古田重然の妹を娶ったと伝えられる。
sen.e: Kenchu YABUNOUCHI, the first family head, was a student of Jo TAKENO, and had a close relation with SEN no Rikyu who was a senior student; he had hereditary succession from Rikyu and was married with a sister of Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA through the good offices of Rikyu.

Kenchu YABUNOUCHI, the first family head, was a student of Jo TAKENO and good friends with the older SEN no Rikyu; he succeeded Rikyu and was married with a sister of Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA due to Rikyu's matchmaking.

Kenchu YABUNOUCHI, the first family head, was a student of Jouou TAKENO and good friends with the older SEN no Rikyu; he succeeded Rikyu and was married with a sister of Shigenari/Shigeteru FURUTA due to Rikyu's matchmaking.

sen.j: しかし豊臣秀吉に茶堂として重用された利休とは対照的に、洛北に隠棲して孤高の茶三昧であったとされる。
sen.e: Compared to Rikyu, who was in charge of an important post as sado (a tea master served to a person of exalted rank) appointed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, he retired and lived in rakuhoku (north of Kyoto, the capital) and was indulged in tea ceremony isolatedly.
However, unlike Rikyu, who was appointed to the important post of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's tea master, Kenchua led a secluded life in the north, immersing himself in the tea ceremony.
However, unlike Rikyu, who was appointed to the important post of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's tea master, Kenchu led a secluded life in the north, immersing himself in the tea ceremony.

sen.j: 利休死後すぐに聚楽第に召し出されて茶堂を務めた時期があるがまもなく辞している。
sen.e: He was called to Jurakudai, the residence of Hideyoshi, just after the death of Rikyu and served as sado; however, he left the position soon.
Upon Rikyu's death, he was summoned to Jurakudai, Hideyoshi's residence, to serve as tea master, though he soon resigned.
Upon Rikyu's death, he was summoned to Jurakudai, Hideyoshi's residence, to serve as tea master, though he soon resigned.

sen.j: 義兄である織部とも親しく、燕庵は織部から譲り受けた茶室である。
sen.e: He was also close to Oribe, his brother-in-law, and Ennan was a tea room inherited from Oribe.
He was also close to Oribe, his brother-in-law, inheriting the tea room, Ennan, from him.
He was also close to Oribe, his brother-in-law, inheriting the tea room, Ennan, from him.

sen.j: 2代真翁は、寛永11年（1634年）より西本願寺13世良如上人に迎えられて茶道師家となり、以降西本願寺の手厚い庇護を受けることになる。
sen.e: Shino, the second head of the family, was invited to Nishi Honganji Temple by Ryonyo Jonin, the 13th head of the temple, and the family became a tea master in 1634, and it was treated well by Nishi Honganji Temple.

In 1634, Shino, the second head of the family, was invited to Nishi Honganji Temple by Ryonyo Jonin, the 13th head of the temple, with the family becoming tea ceremony instructors and continuing to receive the patronage of Nishi Honganji Temple.

In 1634, Shino, the second head of the family, was invited to Nishi Hongan-ji Temple by Ryonyo Shonin, the 13th head of the temple, with the family becoming tea ceremony instructors and continuing to receive the patronage of Nishi Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: 現在の藪内家も西本願寺より与えられた土地にある。
sen.e: The residence of the current Yabunouchi family is located in the land given by Nishi Honganji Temple.
The residence of the current Yabunouchi family is located on land given by Nishi Honganji Temple.
The residence of the current Yabunouchi family is located on land given by Nishi Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: 真翁は利休の養子である千少庵と親しかったらしい。
sen.e: It is said that Shino was close to SEN no Shoan, the adopted son of Rikyu.
It is said that Shino was close to SEN no Shoan, the adopted son of Rikyu.
It is said that Shino was close to SEN no Shoan, the adopted son of Rikyu.

sen.j: 4人の男子があり、長子3代剣翁の他は、相馬藩、徳島藩、熊本藩へ代々出仕した。
sen.e: He had four sons; the three sons except for Keno, the first son and the third head of the family, became officers of the domain of Soma, the domain of Tokushima, and the domain of Kumamoto respectively for generations.

His four sons, with the exception of the eldest,Keno, who became the third head of the family, became officers of the domain of Soma, the domain of Tokushima, and the domain of Kumamoto for generations.

His four sons, with the exception of the eldest, Keno, who became the third head of the family, became officers of the domain of Soma, the domain of Tokushima, and the domain of Kumamoto for generations.

sen.j: 後に4代剣渓の弟が分家して鍋島藩に出仕している。
sen.e: Later, the brother of Kenkei, the fourth head of the family, established a branch house and became an officer of the domain of Nabeshima.
Later, the brother of Kenkei, the fourth head of the family, established a branch house and became an officer of the domain of Nabeshima.
Later, the brother of Kenkei, the fourth head of the family, established a branch house and became an officer of the domain of Nabeshima.

sen.j: 5代竹心は藪内家中興と称せられ、千家中興と言われる表千家7代如心斎らと同時期の人であるが、富裕町人を大量に受け入れ華やかに変貌しはじめた三千家に対しては批判的であった。
sen.e: Chikushin, the 5th head of the family, was deemed as a symbol of restoration of the Yabunouchi family who lived in the same period with Joshinsai, the 7th head of Omotesenke, a school of tea ceremony, who was supposed to be an image of Senke Restoration: Chikushin was critical of Sansenke which started to change brightly having a lot of rich people in a merchant class.

Although the 5th head of the family, Chikushin, who is known for reviving the Yabunouchi family, lived at the same time as Joshinsai, the 7th head of the Omotesenke school and the symbol of Senke restoration, he was critical of the Sansenke for becoming pompous by accepting large numbers of wealthy merchants.

Although the fifth head of the family, Chikushin, who is known for reviving the Yabunouchi family, lived at the same time as Joshinsai, the 7th head of the Omotesenke school and the symbol of Senke restoration, he was critical of the Sansenke for becoming pompous by accepting large numbers of wealthy merchants.

sen.j: 『真向翁』『源流茶話』など多くの著作を残し、そこで利休時代の茶道の本筋に立ち返るべきと論じている。
sen.e: He wrote a lot of books such as "Mamuki no Okina (an essay)" and "Genryu Chawa (a tea book)", and discussed that the tea ceremony must return to the main stream existed in the period of Rikyu.

He wrote many books, including "Mamuki no Okina (The Straightforward Elder)" and "Genryu Chawa (Discussions of Authentic Tea Ceremony)", that argued for a return to the original tea ceremony of Rikyu's time.
sen.cmt: Added translations of book titlesRevised for clarity
sen.e: He wrote many books, including "Mamuki no Okina (The Straightforward Elder)" and "Genryu Chawa (Discussions of Authentic Tea Ceremony)", that argued for a return to the original tea ceremony of Rikyu's time.

sen.j: 藪内流の精神「正直清浄 礼和質朴」は竹心の言葉に由来する。
sen.e: The spirit of the Yabunouchi school, "Honesty, purity, thanking and harmony, simplicity", came from the words of Chikushin.
The spirit of the Yabunouchi school, "honesty, purity, humility, simplicity", came from the words of Chikushin.
sen.cmt: Not sure of a good translation for "礼和"
sen.e: The spirit of the Yabunouchi school, 'honesty, purity, courtesy, simplicity', came from the words of Chikushin.
sen.cmt: " "→' '「礼和」を courtesy としました。

sen.j: 以降も、町人文化に対応した三千家とは対照的に、西本願寺に加えて武家との交わりを重ねて華美を戒め古儀に徹しながら幕末を迎える。
sen.e: On the contrary of Sansenke, which went along with the townsmen culture, the school had close communication with samurai families in addition to Nishi Honganji Temple, and focused on avoiding luxuriousness and maintaining ancient rites to the end of Edo Period.

In contrast with the Sansenke, which went along with merchant culture, the Yabunouchi-ryu remained close to samurai families, as well as Nishi Honganji Temple, and focused on avoiding pomp and maintaining ancient rites to the end of Edo Period.

In contrast with the Sansenke, which went along with merchant culture, the Yabunouchi-ryu remained close to samurai families, as well as Nishi Hongan-ji Temple, and focused on avoiding pomp and maintaining ancient rites to the end of Edo Period.

sen.j: 幕末の動乱は藪内家にもおよび、元治元年（1864年）の兵火で家屋は全て焼失しているが、真翁以来の庇護者であった西本願寺の援助によって速やかに復旧を遂げている。
sen.e: The Yabunouchi family also had the influence of disturbance at the end of Edo period, and the residence was completely burnt down by fire caused by a battle in 1864; however, it had been restored soon thanks to the support of Nishi Honganji Temple, which had been its custodian since the period of Shino.

The Yabunouchi family was also affected by the upheaval of the end of the Edo period, and the residence was completely burnt down during fighting in 1864; however, it was soon rebuilt thanks to the support of Nishi Honganji Temple, which had been its benefactor since the Shino's time.

The Yabunouchi family was also affected by the upheaval of the end of the Edo period, and the residence was completely burnt down during fighting in 1864; however, it was soon rebuilt thanks to the support of Nishi Hongan-ji Temple, which had been its benefactor since the Shino's time.

sen.j: なお藪内家を象徴する茶室である燕庵は、相伝を受けた者に限り絶対忠実に写すことを許され、また家元で失なわれた際には最も古い写しが家元に寄付されるという定めがあり、このとき摂津有馬にあった写しが移築されて現在に伝わっている。
sen.e: Only a person who had hereditary succession was permitted to copy Ennan, the tea room which is the symbol of the Yabunouchi family, only if it is copied absolutely identically, and if the original room at the head of the school is lost, the oldest copy must be donated to the head; the current building was a copy which was located in Settsu-Arima and transferred to the current location.

Only the successor is permitted to copy Ennan, the tea room which is the symbol of the Yabunouchi family, and only if it is copied absolutely identically, and if the original room at the head of the school is lost, the oldest copy must be donated to the head; the current building was a copy which was located in Settsu-Arima and transferred to the current location.
sen.cmt: Revisedd to make less wordyPunctuationI thin k this would be better split into 2 sentences.
sen.e: Only the successor is permitted to copy Ennan, the tea room which is the symbol of the Yabunouchi family, and only if it is copied absolutely identically, and if the original room at the head of the school is lost, the oldest copy must be donated to the head; the current building was a copy which was located in Settsu-Arima and transferred to the current location.

sen.j: 維新後は諸流派同様に困難な時期を送るが、これを乗り越えて現在に至る。
sen.e: The family had difficulty after the Imperial restoration similarly to the other schools, but it got over the period and survives to today.
Like other schools, the Yabounouchi-ryu experienced difficulty after the Imperial restoration, but it survived and continues to exist today.
sen.cmt: Changed word orderRevised for clarity, naturalness
sen.e: Like other schools, the Yabunouchi-ryu experienced difficulty after the Meiji restoration, but it survived and continues to exist today.
